dialogue.string: 1�Show your 3?????Sounds like a plan.No can do.
1�Did you leave it behind?Yes, silly me.No, I've got it right here.
1�You bring forth the 3???? before the Winged Scourg
1�The Winged Scourge casts a burning stare in your directio
1� , can you show him the proof of your bonds to this forest, too?
e.� ! Do you want to get us burned to a crisp!?
1�...Or are you saying that because you <gasp> left it back in Adoulin?
1�How could you!?
1�Wait a minute...
1�Ugh!This better be the last time you try to pull my leg like that,  ! I don't think my heart can take much more.
1�You refer to the founder king by his first name? So...you knew him personally?
1�But he lived centuries upon centuries ago! You couldn't possibly--
1�Yes, I am. They're the Naakuals, right?
1�That must be Terrcualn.
1�I recall reading about him during one of my trips to the library. What was the title of the book, though...?
1�Aha, ??His Majesty and the Golden Beast??! That's it!
1�Umm... Where they fought, you say? Well...that would be...
1� , what do we do? I don't remember that detail at all.
1�...Aha, it's a trick question! The story makes no mention of where they fought!
1�I'm so embarrassed,  ... I don't want to admit it, but maybe he's right after all.
1�It was silly of me to come here knowing so little.
1�If I'm to make amends, there's only one thing left to do.
1� , let's burrow deep into Adoulin's vault of knowledge, leaving no page unturned in our wake!
1� , I'm always glad to have you by my side. I don't know what I would've done...
1�Then you know details hidden from our eyes and ears?
1�Sajj'aka, you mentioned that it was August--the founder king--who released you.
1�Sajj'aka...
1�As pioneers whose charge is to open up the jungle, clashes with the Naakuals are inevitable. We knew it from the very beginning.
1�Sajj'aka! Let me interject.
1�You said that the Naakuals are to guard the six entrances to the Serpentine Labyrinth.
1�Our annals state that there are seven Naakuals, but you mention only six entrances.
1�You mean...August's sworn enemies?
1�August's sword--Ortharsyne--led me here to this very spot.

1�Before I began private tutelage, my father often read to us a poem, and one verse sticks out to me to this day:??When disaster is nigh and evil has descended, brandish the sword to the heavens, and all shall be mended.??
1�The light that pierced the sky signaled the top of this peak. I know the founder king left something--or someone--very important with you.
1�But Ortharsyne was not our only beacon.
1�The twinned World Tree, whose power wanes even as we speak, gave 6???? to  ...as it gave something to you.
1�The winds of change are sweeping Ulbuka, threatening to blow away all she embraces.

1�And this change bodes ill for all of us. Horrific beasts of unforeseen origin are appearing in greater numbers by the day. Landshivers threaten to knock over even the stoutest building in Adoulin. Trees wither and die, and the water runs foul.
1�Tell me, Sajj'aka--why? Why is this happening? Isn't there anything we can do to stop it?
1�Please. If you know anything, share it with us!
1�The spirits of the past...do you mean those who commanded the Cimmerian Adherents?
1�It can't be...Sajj'aka, you stared into the Serpentine Labyrinth and lived. You must know something--!
1� ! Wh-whatever has gotten into you!?
1�But, surely there must be something? Maybe if there was some way to save the World Tree...
1�So if we were to find a similar branch...
1�Rhazowa...we only know it as a land wrapped in the flames of war.
1�If it's as simple as going there, then--
1�Where could his scales possibly...?
1�Please, mighty dragon! We need your aid!
1�But this is the will of the king himself!
1�I've been trying to say that the whole time! Don't you agree,  ?
1�See? We both think so!
t.� , you don't either, do you? Because if you do...
1�A huge seal?
1�And the landshivers...are those caused by the founder king, too?
1�Help him understand? I don't follow.
1�Wait...is that why he said that the curse must never be lifted?
1�No, I'm not sure that's the case.
1� , do you remember the first time we met?
1�It was outside the forest, when a young girl no older than eight went outside the city walls to find some herbs to help her grandfather.
1� , isn't that a stroke too cruel? How could you forget about Tiana?
1�For Tiana, it was her grandfather. For my brother, it is the people of Adoulin.
1�Where are you thinking, Morimar?
1�So if we could find a way in...
1�We would need more than their permission?
1�I'll come with you,  !
1�...You're right. I'm needed in the city.
1� , I know you can do this without me. There are things in Adoulin that only I can handle.
1�Among them, gathering information. And I am sure you'll do the same, though in a different way.
1�I know searching for those scales will be dangerous, and it may mean your life--but there's no one I would trust more.
1�After all...we each have our role to play.
1�And Darrcuiln...I know that you talk to   telepathically.
1�Could you...could you do the same with me?
1�Is this...6????? Like the one August brought back from Rhazowa?
1� , you have traveled through Vana'diel. There is a certain song that you perhaps may have heard of.
1�It shelters us in times of need.
1�It has been around longer than Adoulin, and some scholars assert that it was originally sung in a tongue not known to the people of Vana'diel.
1�And the section we know is but one part of a greater whole.
1�Our interpretation may be wrong, but nonetheless, it is a beacon that guides Adoulinians in dark times.
1�The Goddess of the Dawn has served as our eternal protector, and we cannot help but think these words spilled forth from her lips.
1�Hearing this song now, I feel like all hope is not lost. That tomorrow will be a brighter day.
1�As Sajj'aka said, maybe we do not have the three forces that sealed Hades away so long ago...but we have something now that they did not.
1�Just like a holy dragon rising valiantly from the peaks...Just like a young tree stretching defiantly towards the heavens...
1�Ask the World Tree? How would we go about doing that?
1�An apology? For what?
1�But if you know about him now, then does that mean...?
1�That's the reason why we've come. To seek your wisdom and experience against your old foes.
1�Just forget about him?
1�How would he go about doing that?
1�You mean...
1�Blood sigils?
1�I don't understand.
1�<Gulp>
1�Teodor, why do you know all this? Please, tell me!
1�No, you can't mean--!
1�But how? Why!?
1�I understand.
1�But I have one request. Though I cannot take part, I would like to be present--as one of August's heirs.
1�Teodor had always struck me as being more than he let on...
1�But never would I have imagined he lived during the time of the founder king.
1�It was he who suggested that I register at the Pioneers' Coalition so I could leave for the jungle more...formally.
1�But given that pioneers always spread rumors about him drowning in drink and gambling at the Mummers' Coalition, I can't fault you for thinking that.
s.�Begone from here. You frail mortals should have thought twice before assscending this peak.
1�I have no patience for those who desssecrate the forest. Depart at once.
1�That blade...
n.�Hmmm... Ortharsssyne and 6????...
1�You mean to tell me that you are not like the rest of those pillagers, but ssstaunch believers in August and his desire to preserve the forest?
1�Of courssse I knew him, for I am Sajj'aka.
1�Not only did I know the first Adoulin king, I ssswore my allegiance to him.
1�Was it centuries ago? Millennia? Time flows for many thingsss, but upon Sajj'aka it touchesss not.
1�Seasss change. Landsss change. Even should the starsss fade from existence, the covenant made with Augussst shall not break.
1�In my eyes, the lives of your kind are as delicate and transient as bubbles in a ssstream, your moments of glory mere sssparks from flint.
1�Inconsssequential, insssignificant, insssubstantial--such is how I came to conceive of your peoples.
1�Augussst has been the only exception.
1�His aura shone brighter than my refulgent scales, and his resolve was ssstrong enough to wrest me from the realm of shadows.
1�That is not the lone justification for why my memory of him will persissst until the end of time, but it is an important one.
1�And what of you, ssspindly-legged foal?
1�Does the ressspect for the king you claim to harbor within that miniscule bosom of yours amount to even a drop in the sea compared to what I showed him while he was alive?
1�<Snort>Hopefully you can at least answer this sssimple question.
1�As a preface...you are aware of the ssseven guardians that protect the Ulbukan hinterland, are you not?
1�Is that the ephemeral sssobriquet they have been given by your kind? Very well.
1�I shall not waste my breath explaining the ressst.
1�However, there was one more guardian who fought alongside August...a worthy tiger whose fur shone a lussstrous gold.
1�Ah, booksss. An inconvenient form of immortality, but perhapsss the best your ephemeral kind can hope for. If you are truly learned, you should have no qualms about a simple tessst.
1�Pray tell me, where did August meet Terrcualn in combat?
1�Confidence conceals ignorance only when the other party is ignorant as well, you misssguided fool.
1�In the end, you care as little for August as I care for dissemblers.

1�The one who saved me from that place where even the faintest hint of light is ssswallowed whole...nestlingsss such as you could never hope to fathom his greatnesss. I was foolish to believe otherwise.
1�I will not ssstand for this a moment longer.
1�I know not why you tressspassed upon this land, and I no longer care.
1�There is nothing left to dissscuss, for you have proven beyond a doubt that you are incapable of understanding August's will.
1�Petulant children. Did I not ask you to be gone from my sssight?
1�Then it is my sssworn duty as a protector of this land to confirm if your intent matches your words.
1�It matters little which of you engages in this tessst I am to put forth. But anger me further, and your life is forfeit.
1�Well, how unexpected! The ?[boy/girl] is putting on airs!
1�Yet pride always comes before a fall. Let us hope that the fire in your eyesss does not become quenched by the avalanche of failure.
1�And an avalanche it shall be, ssshould you make even one misstep. Let the first trial begin.
1�The king of legends was sssaved by a tiger whose mane looked to be woven from golden threads. Where was the site of their struggle?
1�Dare the two of you mock me!?
1�It has been many years since I have conversssed with your kind. Perhaps you merely...misspoke. I shall grant you a reprieve.
1�Dare the two of you mock me!?
1�It has been many years since I have conversssed with your kind. Perhaps you merely...misspoke. I shall grant you a reprieve.
1�The truth is never a low-hanging fruit, free for all to pluck. It comes only to those willing to snatch it from the heavens.
1�Though I did not bear witness to this truth, Terrcualn and August incessantly regaled me with every lassst detail, and I could recite the story by heart.
1�Beyond doubt, the two ssstruggled valiantly, with August staring straight into the abyss and dragging forth victory from its gaping maw.
1�Terrcualn thus chose to ssserve the fabled one, learning to love him much as I did.
1�Now, for the second test.
1�Terrcualn's cub was entrusted to one of August's most trusted generals. I assume you came across this fact in your studies.
1�Who was this man?
1�Do you make a mockery of August's sssacrifice? Are you such a buffoon that you cannot answer so much as the name of the man who fought by his side?
1�If only he knew that...No. I must have misheard.
1�Come, tell me your anssswer once more.
1�Do you make a mockery of August's sssacrifice? Are you such a buffoon that you cannot answer so much as the name of the man who fought by his side?
1�If only he knew that...No. I must have misheard.
1�Come, tell me your anssswer once more.
1�Yes, that is correct. A truly powerful individual indeed, though his ssstar did not shine as brightly as his lord's.
1�August's eleven generals were the only men and women to ever move my heart. That remainsss true to this day.
1�Let us move to the final quessstion.
1�When all seemed lost and the king made his last ssstand, where was it that he fought tooth and claw?
1�Never have I heard tales of such a location, but its name alone sends shivers up my ssspine.
1�I deign to give you one more chance.
1�Never have I heard tales of such a location, but its name alone sends shivers up my ssspine.
1�I deign to give you one more chance.
1�That is correct. Young one, you have prepared well for this encounter.
1�I recognize you as heritors to August's will, and will grant you one brief audience.
1�There are limitsss to that which man has recorded in his annals, but as I said before--truth is a fruit found only by the intellectually ravenous.
1�Beyond doubt.
1�Your memory is sssharp as a fresh blade, young one.And what about you, ?[son/daughter] of man?
1�Do you recall this tale?
1�Hmm...I had taken you both for fools, but now I sssee that you are worthy.
1�Ha...hahaha!
1�Quite the show you've put on for me!But your honesssty and candor are refreshing.
1�Be thankful that your friend is both meticulousss and sound of mind.
1�Yes, that tale is yet another in this series of truthsss. I am not of Ulbukan origin.
1�The time is not right for me to explain the ssstory in its entirety, but suffice to say...
1�I was long chained down in a terrible domain, and it was the king who releasssed me from my prison.
1�Never again will I return there. Nor will they...
1�??Homeland.?? Quite the pretty phrase, washing away reality with a thin veneer of nossstalgia. No, my ??homeland?? is not a place to which I desire to return.
1�And I will take no further questionsss on the matter.
1�You mentioned earlier the beings you know as the ??Naakuals.??
1�So...you have vanquished them.
1�Perhaps it is as he said...I should not look down on the ?[sssons/daughtersss] of man.
1�Hmm...pioneering...Unsssurprising, given that they are the guardians of Ulbuka.
1�We are quite alike, the Naakualsss and I. We are all residents of a land we cannot call our own, rescued from fate by the one you call the founder king.
1�They obeyed his will much like I did, and when he ordered them to guard sssix locations around Ulbuka, they were bound to obey. That is how they came to protect this land.
1�The ancient pact declared that they were to remain dissstant from the affairs of mortals and shelter the jungle from harm.
1�Yet countlesss years have passed since the king made his request manifest. Perhaps too many years.
1�Some who witnessed those times firsthand have had their memories fade as the centuries passed, and have long forgotten the very reason for their sssworn task.
1�And not jussst the ??why??...but also the ??what.??
1�It is not the jungle they pledged to protect.
1�They were scattered throughout the six reaches of Ulbuka, to be sssure, but not for the reason you think.
1�They were sent to guard the six entrances to what you refer to as the Serpentine Labyrinth.
1�When August made his last ssstand, he bid Morimar and I to return to the surface without him.
1�Our purpose--given by the king himself--was not to guard his side. It was to deliver his orders unto...
1�...the Naakuals. They were to seal the entrances to the labyrinth and ensure that nary so much as a man's breath penetrate into its recesses.
1�Correct.
1�He was...different from the rest.
1�In ancient times, he was referred to as ??The Deathborne Xol,?? and his purpose was to ssserve the hallowed leader of the Cimmerian Adherents.
1�Indeed. He was one of the Xol Triumvirate.
1�But during his fierce classshes with August, he came to see the light.
1�I know not where he is or what his tasssk is.Perhaps...
1�No, ssspeculation is not my forte. He is impossible for me to read.
1�The seals on the Serpentine Labyrinth wear thin. The spirits of the past are beginning to reawaken.
1�The Lord of the Serpentine Labyrinth...Hades.
1�Darkness threatens to choke this land once more. He returnsss.
1�The sssmell of the wind...the undulations of the land...It is now as it was then.
1�Like a harsh wind chipping away at a boulder, his return is sluggish...but inevitable.
1�You too, child, must sssense it. Forces antithetical to all life strengthen with each passing day.
1�As they wax, the power of the World Tree wanes.
1�Having lost its twin, it coalesced all its energies into its roots and took hold deep within Ulbukan soil.
1�It then ssspread throughout the land, quelling all the evil that sought to consume it.
1�Countless years have passed since then, and, as the World Tree aged, it began to lose its potency.
1�The landshivers are but a physical manifessstation of this phenomenon. Each shudder is the World Tree trembling in agony.
1�Then all that August worked to contain will ssspill out onto the surface.
1�Hades' wait is almost over, his black heart is growing stronger as we speak.
1�Calamity will befall us once again.
1�We cannot.
1�Young child and her young friend...I am but a relic of the passst.
1�Would that August were alive, things may be different. If not his body, then at least his ssspirit...
1�But it is still chained within the Serpentine Labyrinth's most inner recessses.
1�During August's crusade, he was ruthlessly devoted to his cause, and the World Tree was at the height of its power.
1�These three forces combined to seal that dark malady deep within.
1�Yet dessspite the most favorable of circumstances, we failed to eliminate the threat completely.
1�This time, we have no light of hope to guide us.
1�Though I remain in this realm, I still bear the wounds I suffered during that ssstruggle.
1�As I alluded to before, even if I were healthy, the founder king's ssspirit is trapped, and the World Tree has begun to crumble.
1�Yet despite all this, mankind insists on working its utmost to destroy the wilds!
1�How can you possibly underssstand my pain!?
1�How many times must we knock them down before they cease to rise up once more!?
1�Ssstop that this instant!
1�<Sigh>Forgive my sudden outburssst.
1�Whatever the case, our three lights of hope have been extinguished.
1�The world is made up of one sssimple truth: if something can grow old, it can die.
1�But perhaps...perhaps there is a way to reverse the process.
1�Firssst, a brief lesson. The World Tree's origins lie not in Ulbuka.
1�To hear August tell it, he had retrieved a young branch of the World Tree from a far-off land, and planted it here, in this continent.
1�It sprang forth from the sssoil and began to bud before one turn of the moon, its limbs stretching so high they must have touched Altana herself.
1�If we were to do the same thing......And this time, the rootsss are already here to work with.
1�Then the World Tree would burssst into existence much as it did then...only faster.
1�A Lightsland. The World Tree grew in a sssanctified place filled with light and surrounded by serene waters.
1�In a place that was once called Rhazowa.
1�There was once a Lightsssland on that frozen continent......Nevertheless, its presence is but a memory etched onto a tattered canvas.
1�When the World Tree sssensed changes occurring here, it gifted a piece of itself, creating a new Lightsland here.
1�I can feel it. Soft vibrations in the land, calling me there.
1�No. Even though you have seen the reality, there is nothing you can do.
1�I, and I alone, have the power to accesss the Lightsland.
1�But the trauma I have sssuffered is too great, and my constitution is too frail.
1�Those blasphemous entities ssstripped me of my scales, cursed them, and scattered them throughout the land.
1�This is why my wounds will never heal. I cannot fly as long as my ssscales are held captive. Not now, not ever.
1�Even the slightest flap of my wings sends jolts of pain down my ssspine.
1�Circling the mountaintop is all I can bear before I am forced to make landfall. Arriving at the Lightsssland? Beyond question.
1�I have searched many of your lifetimesss for even one, but to no avail.
1�I have no other avenues to try, and cannot disperse the evil.
1�Darrcuiln...and Morimar, too.And alssso...
1�...You two. Even a caged Opo-opo knows that it cannot reach the pamama tree.
1�This was your doing, I assume?
1�I know not what you plan, but I could have my answer engraved on a ssstone tablet and you would just claim to be illiterate.
1�No. Begone.
1�What you would asssk of me cannot be done. August told us to impart one lesson to the people--never again were they to set foot in the wilds.
1�Sssee, Morimar? Even an outsider such as ?[he/she] knows the tale.
1�Do you not see your role as an accomplice in this travesssty?
1�What would you know of the truth? Morimar and I were there, while your far ancestors were doubtless still bickering over some petty land dispute.
1�In any event, the king had but one wish--that none ever enter the continent.
1�But the children of men are foolhardy. Their lives last but an inssstant, and thus their capacity for wisdom is lacking.
1�They knew his dying words, yet from then until this very day, they never abandoned their desire to terrorize the jungle.
1�The fools are not aware that the World Tree's roots are buried deep within the Serpentine Labyrinth, shutting in the forces of darkness from the outssside world.
1�No, not only are they ignorant--they continue to harm the Tree with each breath they take.
1�Numberless are the years I spent watching humanity's pernicious deeds from atop this frigid peak.
1�I am confident that the king would not have wavered in these dark times. Man is to leave this place.
1�You ssspeak truth. A storm threatens to tear us all apart.
1�The World Tree's power has begun to fade, and my wingsss will not carry me for more than a few brief moments.
1�The Naakualsss have been embroiled in conflict from dawn to dusk since the moment Morimar emerged from that cursed labyrinth, and even they have begun to forget why.
1�That is correct, child. Your sojourn was but pure misconception.
1�...Conflicted?
1�Is that so...
1�How...how could you possibly know that?
1�And where would you suggessst?
1�Why would...?
1�At lassst, I see why you brought them before me.
1�...6Morimar, my old friend and battle brother.
1�And you, who bears proof of your deeds.
1�Ssso it is as Morimar said. My scales were sealed away in that cursed place.
1�I know you can find them all.To think...all those yearsss I wasted searching in the wrong places.
1�But remember--even if you find them all, I will not be at full strength, and will not be able to penetrate the Ssserpentine Labyrinth any more than you.
1�Hades, my hatred for you grows deeper with each breath I exhale! , I know you will sssucceed!
1�My scales...I can ssscarcely believe they are all here.
1�My friend, these outsidersss...what did you call them?
1�Color me impresssed, Morimar. You have certainly been busy when not under my gaze.
1�??An age of adventure...??
1�Ssspeaking of powers long forgotten, back in those olden times, there were three forces that made all this possible.
1�The savage yet noble hero, King August.
1�The twinned World Tree, which watches over all life.
1�I thought...I thought all had been lossst.
1�We worked as hard as we could, yet it was all we could do to ssseal away Hades.
1�And now, with those forces in a precipitousss decline, I thought there was no way to save this land.
1�Up until this moment, I had taken these phenomena to herald the beginning of the end.
1�I thought myself irreparably shattered, yet now my woundsss are mended. This is all thanks to you.
1�With this, you should be able to ressstore the World Tree.
1�Two of the three are ready to be brought to bear. Now what about August, whose spirit is held hostage in the Serpentine Labyrinth?
1�If we only had sssomething that could compare to his valor...
1�When August recovered the sssapling from Rhazowa and brought it here, he planted it in one of the most sacred areas of Ulbuka.
1�But such an area would have long since fallen to the choking miasssmas of the Serpentine Labyrinth.
1�Were you able to affix it to the roots of the exisssting World Tree, you may be able to bring it back to life...but I have not the faintest notion of how.
1�Unfortunately. But do not fret, young one. Should you desssire to aid the World Tree, all you need do is ask it.
1�I see you are ssstarting to realize at last.
1�Your first order of business is to restore the World Tree. That is the only way to bolssster Ulbuka against the evil within.
1�The easssterly winds have shifted, young ones, heralding the revival of his malicious decadence.
1�Calling it an ??ill portent?? would make mockery of the sssacrifices August and his generals made...that we all made.
1�But we have yet to bear witness to breaches in the jungle's integrity itself, indicating that neither Hades nor his ssservants have crested in power.
1�If they were to fully awaken, the land would split in twain, choking tendrils dragging pioneers into a bottomless crevasse. No, what you see now is merely a foreshadowing of what is to come.
1�You speak truthfully.
1�Balamor...That name is not familiar to me. And you believe he is the most recent incarnation of the undying horde'sss leader.
1�And I shall lend my aid as well. Now that I have recovered--
1�Why start with more ephemeral topicsss when we can focus on someone close to our hearts: Morimar.
1�Sssurely you understand now, Princess.
1�Though he once ssserved under the monster, he is now one of the seven...the Undying Naakual.
1�In the flesh.
